SC Academic Reports
emphasizes teaching
By JAY GOODGOLD
After six months of research
and revision, the Student Council's Academic Reports on undergraduate education and faculty
input were released to the Academic Council and the University at
large yesterday.
An eight man task force headed by SC President Andy Savitz
compiled the 200-plus page report. The study- touched on all
aspects of undergraduate education, including faculty and departmental attitudes and teaching assistants, and offered a list of suggestions designed to improve undergraduate academic life.
Divided into two parts, the reports contain an introduction
which states their purpose as well
as general suggestions for the entire academic community. The
main body contains the individual reports on professors and departments.
One suggestion expressed a desire for a change in the University's outlook on undergraduate instruction. Teaching, the report
states, should be greatly expanded, especially among full-time fa-

culty members.
The report's recommendation
on undergraduate teaching proposes a revamping of the University's faculty priorities. The "publish or perish" syndrome which
faculty members are accused of
would be altered if the report's
suggestions are followed, to one
of "teach or transfer."
Although one half research,
one half teaching curriculum is
cited as the ideal structure for faculty activity, the reports suggested that those professors especially gifted in teaching be allowed
to devote most of their time to
undergraduate education without
emphasis on research.
"Certain faculty members
should be allowed to spend the
majority of their time doing outstanding teaching rather than research," the reports stated.
Other suggestions in the reports include allowing students
to enroll in 600 level courses and
the initiation of BA-MA programs in all departments.

Day' address given by Sanford
By PATRICE GALLAGHER
Terry Sanford, president of
Duke University and former governor of North Carolina, criticized present governmental efforts to meet the challenges of
the energy crisis, at Friday's
Commemoration Day Ceremonies. He called for a "departure
from the casual, lackadaisical,
and indifferent effort which characterizes the national government at present."
He also stressed the importance of greater government fun
ding to university research, because "this tremendous research
resource is already here, already
available, already in position to
go to Work tomorrow, or for that
matter, this afternoon."
As well as delivering the Commemoration Address, Sanford

was awarded the Degree of
Doctor of Laws in recognition of
his achievements in the fields of
government, education and human rights, particularly during
his term as governor of North
Carolina.
Governors
Sanford was one of the first
Southern governors to institute a
policy of equal opportunity in
state and private hiring. He is increasingly mentioned as a-possible Democratic candidate for
the Presidency in 1976.
Dr. George W. Corner, an alumnus of the Johns Hopkins
School of Medicine and professor
emeritus of embryology, was also
awarded the Degree of Doctor of
Laws. Corner has made several
important contributions to research in human reproduction,

having discovered with Willard
Allen the ovarian hormone, progesterone. Corner is currently
executive officer of the American
Philosophical Society.
President Muller conferred the
honorary degrees upon both
Sanford and Corner, and also
spoke briefly about the state of
the Johns Hopkins Institutions.
Muller revealed that $70,124,890
have, to date, been pledged or
given in the Hopkins Hundreds
fundraising campaign. He noted
that Hopkins' annual budgets are
"still in balance," and our present financial situation "finds us
lean but very fit."
Music for the cermony was
provided by the
Goucher-Hopkins Chorus, led by
George Woodhead, and the
Washington Brass Ensemble.

brotherhood.. Although each one
is phrased differently, words like

it with abstinence. Thus the
seeming contradiction of revelry
and love of virtue can be resolved.

"sensational" aspects of fraternity

life, the parties, the pranks and the
negative connotations associated
with them. Thus when a fraternity
man's behavior is. childish and inconsiderate it is commonly attributed to the fact, that he is in a
fraternity and such behavior is fostered there. If, however, his behavior is sociable and sincere the
fact that he is in a fraternity is
either forgotten or comes to mind
only as an afterthought.

that, as with any life-style, the fraternity ways can be lived well or
poorly. There will always be some
who wish to experience it as social
competition and must rely on
slurs, stereotyping and peculiar behavior to maintain or elevate their
positiOn in the hierarchy of fraternity social status. But there are
others who make close friendships,
have memorable experiences and
are actively concerned with their
personal growth through the brotherhood. The one is more visible
than the other, and no doubt it is
for this reason that fraternities are
known for their clique-ishness and
crude behavior.

SC Academic Reports
emphasizes teaching
By JAY GOODGOLD
After six months of research
and revision, the Student Council's Academic Reports on undergraduate education and faculty
input were released to the Academic Council and the University at
large yesterday.
An eight man task force headed by SC President Andy Savitz
compiled the 200-plus page report. The study- touched on all
aspects of undergraduate education, including faculty and departmental attitudes and teaching assistants, and offered a list of suggestions designed to improve undergraduate academic life.
Divided into two parts, the reports contain an introduction
which states their purpose as well
as general suggestions for the entire academic community. The
main body contains the individual reports on professors and departments.
One suggestion expressed a desire for a change in the University's outlook on undergraduate instruction. Teaching, the report
states, should be greatly expanded, especially among full-time fa-

culty members.
The report's recommendation
on undergraduate teaching proposes a revamping of the University's faculty priorities. The "publish or perish" syndrome which
faculty members are accused of
would be altered if the report's
suggestions are followed, to one
of "teach or transfer."
Although one half research,
one half teaching curriculum is
cited as the ideal structure for faculty activity, the reports suggested that those professors especially gifted in teaching be allowed
to devote most of their time to
undergraduate education without
emphasis on research.
"Certain faculty members
should be allowed to spend the
majority of their time doing outstanding teaching rather than research," the reports stated.
Other suggestions in the reports include allowing students
to enroll in 600 level courses and
the initiation of BA-MA programs in all departments.

Salary increase continues to lag behind inflation
By MARC DUVOISIN
For the third consecutive year,
the average salary increase for
Hopkins employees will not keep
pace with the rate of inflation.
The planned eight per cent
average increase disclosed yesterday by Business Management administrators, though it may seem
substantial enough, will still not
be sufficient to keep up with the
inflationary spiral, currently estimated at 11 per cent. ,
The always touchy process of
determining faculty salary increases has been further complicated by the dire state of the nation's economy. Faculty members have publicly expressed the
hope that their salary increases
will stay in line with those granted at other universities and remain reasonably close to the ever
escalating cost of living.
Dr. Owen Phillips, Earth and
Planetary Sciences, and Dr. Carl
Christ, Political Economy,the
two Homewood representatives
to the President's Ad Hoc Budgetary Committee, have consistently pointed out that faculty
salary raises have not only fallen
out of line with the rate of inflation, but have dropped in rela-

tion to other universities.
In their recently completed report on the University budget,
Christ and Phillips point out that
faculty salaries at Hopkins have
fallen over the past eight years
from 13th in the country to 28th
by the American Association of
University Professprs ratings.
In a similar vein, Dr. Edwin
Fitzgerald, Mechanics and Material Sciences, made reference to
the fall in relative stature of faculty salaries in a whimsical Sunday Experience presentation entitled: "An Underview of the

Homewood Administration."
In light of the faculty's sensitivity to the ranking of its salaries
with regard to other universities,
the process of determining salaries becomes especially difficult.
Since the eight per cent hike is
not enacted "across the board,"
negotiation of individual salaries
takes place in both the administrative and academic sectors of
the University.
With the faculty, however, the
negotiation of salary raises is a
more complicated affair, since
some academic department chair-

men, have greater leverage in
dealing with the Dean than administrative heads do in dealing
with the Homewood Vice President.
Dean of Arts and Sciences
George Owen said yesterday that
the academic chairmen manipulate the increased salary funds as
they see fit, perhaps increasing
some salaries more than others at
their own discretion.
